assessment_steps.details: The paper explicitly links R-synuclein variants (A30P, A53T) to familial Parkinson's disease pathogenesis via Cu(II) binding abnormalities.
Cu(II) binding assays directly model the molecular mechanism of Parkinson's disease (metal ion dysregulation in synucleinopathies).
Wild-type (WT) and variant (A30P, A53T) proteins are compared across multiple pH conditions (7.2/7.4) and temperatures (37°C).
A53T is explicitly identified as a pathogenic variant, while WT serves as a control. A30P is compared against both WT and A53T.
Binding constants (K values) are reported with pH-dependent statistical significance (e.g., 2.4e9 vs. 4.8e9 for WT vs. A53T).
A53T shows 2x higher K values (4.8e9) than WT (2.4e9) at pH 7.4. A30P exhibits a high-affinity site (1e10) linked to pathogenic oligomers. These deviations meet PS3_moderate/very_strong thresholds.
